discourse_list.title: Matt Taibbi post about USDC transparency concerns

content.content: Matt Taibbi recently posted this article relating to his concerns about USDC, their transparency, and the way that they are managing reserve funds.    taibbi.substack.com    The Financial Bubble Era Comes Full Circle An unstable encounter with a $50 billion stablecoin      After reading, it’s clear to me that MakerDAO is not giving enough consideration to the relatively opaque nature of USDC reserves, which are apparently not held in trust, while reserves of others like Gemini and Paxos are held in trust. MakerDAO’s survival depends on USDC’s solvency. Over 84% of DAI is currently generated from USDC. Nearly 7% of circulating USDC is sitting in Maker PSM. Getting 100% clarity on USDC’s reserves aren’t just a nice-to-have for Maker. It’s a necessity. After reading the post, I hope you agree with me that MakerDAO needs to:  approach Circle to gain unprecedented insight into the state of USDC reserves, OR replace USDC with a more transparently-backed asset, OR begin developing a plan to wind down the PSM concept.  The survival of this entire project may depend on one of these three things happening in the very near future.

The article provided a glimpse into the USD “real world” reserve allocations. 61% are held as cash & cash equivalents (would be interesting to know at which bank (or banks) and if the bank is paying them interest) and the remaining are in “safe” investments, meaning that there is no principal at risk if the investment is held until maturity. They are probably doing the same ALM exercise that we are doing and determining that 61% of USDC is volatile while the remaining USDC can be invested in “longer” duration vehicles. There seems to be a lot more resource and focus on risk management than at the other CeFi projects that have collapsed. But agree that DAI collateral diversification is very important and reducing USDC dependency is crucial not just for reducing any risks associated with Circle but for swinging the DeFi balance back.

It is not the first topic demanding to lower the exposure of DAI to USDC, the risk that DAI may have to the insolvencies of Circle and Coinbase are quite extensive, they are a quite powerful entity, but it is still centralized and regulated, we cannot rename ourselves decentralized if more than 50% DAI is backed by USDC     [Signal Request] Immediately Onboard BUSD & Introduce 0% PSM Signal Archive       A classic example of a post that could age really bad (and I hope not).   “Over 50% of our exposure is in USDC” is not fact enough? You don’t need a clear evidence that one of your debtors is underwater to start managing your risk.   I’m not going to argue with someone from the @Growth-Core-Unit about the crypto-ramps landscape, because I don’t stand a chance. But from the outside, it seems that Binance (like it or not) is one of the biggest ramps in the world.
